channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Science background, or a passing interest in life sciences? Junior/mid-level Perl developer needed in London...
item.description: Friendly and quiet office in London (W1) looking for a Perl (or similar) developer with at least two years experience. Youâ€™re expected to have fullstack experience/abilities, from improvements on the clientâ€™s HTML front-end to backend services. Itâ€™s a small company, so thereâ€™s some fluidility expected between roles - a good place to expand on your jack-of-all-software-trades skillset.

item.title: Dreaming of Perl? Mid/Senior-level developer role in The City of Dreaming Spires
item.description: The Victorian poet Matthew Arnold called Oxford â€˜the city of dreaming spiresâ€™, and even the most unromantic among us would surely agree there is something magical about Oxford on a misty autumnal morning.

item.title: Polyglot required Down Under â€“ Senior Developer role in Melbourne, Australia
item.description: Gâ€™day, Perl Mongers of Australia! Do you have a strong background in Perl, but a desire to learn and apply other languages? This client is looking for a polyglot developer, with a focus on Perl but potential to also use (and be cross-trained in) Scala, Ruby, Python and JavaScript. It is a small, flexible team and there may be the opportunity to undertake some DevOps work too if interested.

item.title: Developer Weekly Newsletter
item.description: Gabor is starting another weekly newsletter: this one is going to provide a curated selection of blog posts published by major tech companies. You can sign up at developer-weekly.com.

item.title: July 2017 Grant Votes
item.description: Tina's grant proposal for YAML::PP has been approved.

item.title: Grant Report: Robust Perl 6 Unicode Support
item.description: An update on Samantha's grant to work on Unicode support in Rakudo.

item.title: Steve Mynott's report on the Swiss Perl Workshop 2017
item.description: A detailed report on the Swiss Perl Workshop.

item.title: NativeCall, using the native trait correctly
item.description: Sylvain explains how to use the native trait when using NativeCall to call a C function from Rakudo.

item.title: On Troll Hugging, Hole Digging, and Improving Open Source Communities
item.description: Zoffix shares some of his thoughts about what makes some communities more welcoming, and easier to join, than others.

item.title: Lance's report on the bug squashathon
item.description: Lance took part in last weekend's bug squashathon, which he was prompted to join in on, as he's started working on a web app using Bailador (the Dancer "port" for Rakudo).

item.title: You're invited: Community Bug SQUASHathon
item.description: On the first Saturday of every month, the Rakudo gang plan to have a bug squashathon. The first one was on the Saturday just gone, but you've got plenty of notice for the next one.

item.title: 2017.35 Serving Cro
item.description: Liz's weekly roundup of Rakudo news, the headline for which is Jonathan's Cro framework for building web services.

item.title: Videos from the Swiss Perl Workshop
item.description: There are videos for some of the talks at the recent Swiss Perl Workshop, now available for your viewing pleasure.

item.title: C comments and regular expressions
item.description: Ben works through matching C-style comments with regular expressions.

item.title: Yak Shaving with Aphra Behn
item.description: For many developers, there comes a time when you decide to write your own blog engine. That time has come for Dave, and his blog engine is called Aphra.

item.title: Perl as PID 1 under Docker
item.description: At CV Library they hit a problem when running Perl as process id 1 inside Docker containers. Tim takes us through the problem, and their solution.

item.title: Stew your dependencies
item.description: Dave scratched his blogging itch, and here VTI tells us how he scratched his packaging itch, by developing stew.

item.title: P5P Mailing List Summary: August 22nd-28th
item.description: Pastel de Nata is a Portuguese egg tart pastry. If you haven't tried one, you should try and track some down, because done well, they're delicious. I'm pretty sure 8 out of 10 P5P participants would agree with me.

item.title: Picking a better Markdown library for bad input
item.description: Anirvan tried what he thinks is invalid markdown with four different markdown modules, and as a result suggests that Text::Markdown::Discount may be a good choice. One of the problems with markdown is that there are a lot of things not covered by the official spec (which is what prompted Common Mark, amongst other things).

item.title: Check compression in web page
item.description: Ben introduces WWW::CheckGzip, a module that will check whether a web page has the correct gzip compression.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: TLS only for www.cpan.org
item.description: The Perl NOC are proposing to switch cpan.org to https-only later in September. Please let them know if you think this might cause any problems, for example for any CPAN clients or other tools.

item.title: #319 - Scratching your itch
item.description:
Two of this week's entries are about tools that people wrote to scratch their own itch. That's always been one of the reasons I like Perl: it seems to encourage you to scratch your own itch.

What itch have you scratched recently? Why not tell us about it.

Neil
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
